greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(1)=1; a(n+1) is either a(n)-n or a(n)+n, where we choose the smallest one which is a positive integer that's not among the values a(1), ..., a(n).
comment: After a(24)=19, there are no more terms because a(24)-24 = -5 is not positive and a(24)+24 = 43 is equal to a(21).

If we only require that a(n+1) be either a(n)-n or a(n)+n, is there a sequence that contains every positive integer exactly once? I.e. can we take a walk on the positive integers, starting at 1 and always moving (either left or right) a distance n on the n-th step, so that we hit every positive integer exactly once?
example: a(9)=13, so a(10) is either 13-9=4 or 13+9=22. But 4 is not available since it equals a(3), so a(10)=22.
xref: Consists of terms 1 through 25 of A063733.
results.author: _Leroy Quet_, Dec 15 2002
